6.34.text: My name is Susan Hewitt and

8.00.text: I'm one of the three people who started the 'Love Dart' article.

12.02.text: What's a Love Dart? -- a Love Dart...  -- Love Dark?

17.47.text: The dart that Cupid shoots a person with?

23.02.text: there were three of us that created the first draft of it.

26.98.text: Never before, really in the history of humanity, have so many people come together

32.74.text: on a volunteer basis to build an extraordinary

36.37.text: resource like this that everybody can use!

39.45.text: So, you just write freely, and your work is edited

44.37.text: and improved by the other people who are working on it.

47.38.text: A love dart is actually a dart like a little arrow

52.17.text: That some land snails and slugs

55.71.text: make inside their body, and they use it before mating.

60.64.text: Each snail or slug tries to stab the other one with a love dart.

65.69.text: Oh my god! So that's how it happens! (laughs)

68.90.text: Because Cupid is a story from ancient Greece,

71.65.text: there might be a real parallel between

74.99.text: Cupid and his love darts, and the snails and their love darts.

78.87.text: I like Wikipedia alot, I'm a big fan -- I love Wikipedia.

82.12.text: When I meet other Wikipedians, inside them there's this light that comes from

86.62.text: building this extraordinary structure of knowledge.

90.13.text: I'm not a believer in 'ignorance is bliss', I think the other way around 'knowledge is power'

93.71.text: so I think Wikipedia is a very powerful asset for the world.

97.80.text: It doesn't matter what your area of specialized knowledge

101.76.text: there's a use for it on Wikipedia.
